I.  THE PROPOSAL 
 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on (i) a proposed 
contingent disaster financing (CDF) facility to the Cook Islands; (ii) a proposed policy-based loan 
to the Republic of Palau; and (iii) proposed policy-based grants to the Federated States of 
Micronesia (FSM), the Republic of Kiribati, the Republic of the Marshall Islands (RMI), the 
Independent State of Samoa, Solomon Islands, the Kingdom of Tonga, Tuvalu, and the Republic 
of Vanuatu for the Pacific Disaster Resilience Program (Phase 3). 
 
2.  The  proposed  CDF  program  will  improve  the  resilience  of  the  participating  Asian 
Development Bank (ADB) Pacific developing member countries (DMCs) to disasters triggered by 
natural hazards and health emergencies. It will support policy actions strengthening resilience to 
disasters and provide a source of financing for timely emergency response and early recovery. 
The program is the third phase of the Pacific Disaster Resilience Program; the first phase was 
approved in December 2017 for Samoa, Tonga, and Tuvalu,1 and the second phase in September 
2019 for FSM, RMI, Solomon Islands, and Tonga.2 In addition, ADB set up country-specific CDF 
programs for the Cook Islands and Palau.3 Phase 3 will provide (i) another round of financing for 
(a) countries that drew down their CDF programs for the coronavirus disease (COVID-19) 
pandemic (the Cook Islands, FSM, RMI, Palau, Samoa, Solomon Islands, Tonga) and (b) Tuvalu, 
which drew down the funds in February 2020 in response to Cyclone Tino; and (ii) CDF for the 
first time for Kiribati and Vanuatu.  
 
II.  PROGRAM AND RATIONALE 
 
A.  Background and Development Constraints 
 
3.  Disasters and health emergencies in the Pacific. ADB’s Pacific DMCs are highly 
exposed to many types of hazards, including tropical cyclones, earthquakes, storm surges, 
tsunamis, volcanic eruptions, floods, droughts, and disease outbreaks. The region experiences a 
disproportionately high share of global disaster impacts relative to the size of its economy and 
population. Disaster risk is increasing because of climate change, poor development planning, 
unplanned urbanization, and ecosystem decline. Climate change can increase the intensity of 
extreme weather events. Sea level rise is increasing erosion and the risk of more destructive 
storm surges and tsunamis, and ocean warming and acidification are destroying the coral reefs 
that form natural coastal barriers. Climate change may also create favorable conditions for the 
distribution of vector-borne and zoonotic diseases.  
 
4.  Pacific DMCs have limited resources and capacity to invest in resilience to natural hazards 
and health risks, and to facilitate timely recovery and reconstruction; they also face further 
challenges because of their remote locations and geographical features. Most have relatively 
small populations that are widely dispersed over multiple islands, many of which are isolated and 
difficult to reach during emergencies. These factors contribute to the relatively high cost and 
delayed delivery of emergency response and reconstruction. The delays exacerbate the indirect 
economic and social costs of disasters, worsen their ultimate impacts, and compromise long-term 
fiscal balances. Disasters can erode many years of economic development gains by damaging 
critical infrastructure, disrupting services, and diverting resources from development spending. 4

5.  Policy  and  institutional  arrangements  for  risk  management.  Disaster  risk 
management (DRM) objectives are generally well articulated within the participating DMCs’ 
policies  and  plans,  and  all  countries  have  defined  the  legal  responsibilities  for  DRM  and 
procedures for declaring a state of emergency or disaster. However, building resilience requires 
actions on many fronts, and the countries remain constrained by limited capacity and competing 
priorities. Women and girls are disproportionately impacted by disasters and face greater barriers 
to participating in, and benefitting from, DRM arrangements. The governments recognize that 
more effort is required to strengthen policy and institutional arrangements, and to strengthen 
capacity to reduce risks and to plan and implement timely and effective responses and early 
recovery at national and local levels. DRM arrangements can be further strengthened by defining 
roles and responsibilities in policies and legislation, and by incorporating climate change and DRM 
into national and sector planning. Sex-disaggregated data and gender analysis can help highlight 
the need to specifically support women and girls through policy actions. The 10 DMCs have, 
through early and decisive action, prevented the spread of COVID-19 within their territories, and 
prepared  their  health  systems  to  manage  imported  cases  as  repatriation  of  nationals  and 
reopening of borders are being introduced.5 In order to contain a possible outbreak, whole-of-
government public health policies and legislation are required to ensure early detection, timely 
activation of emergency response protocols for case management, and cross-sector coordination.  
 
6.  Risk-informed  investment  planning  processes  and  tools.  Capacity  to  deal  with 
disasters and public health emergencies is particularly weak at the local level. Regular capacity 
building and drills are required to ensure successful implementation of emergency response 
plans. National disaster management offices are often underfunded, and health systems are weak 
throughout the Pacific. Physical development and land use planning often give insufficient regard 
to considerations of resilience. Climate and disaster resilience of communities and assets can be 
strengthened by enhancing related strategies and plans; strengthening gender mainstreaming; 
integrating resilience considerations into sector, land use and settlement plans; and ensuring risk 
sensitive asset management, including for state-owned utilities. Capacity for infectious disease 
prevention, detection, and clinical management can be significantly strengthened in all countries, 
including upgrading of local laboratories for COVID-19 testing, expanding quarantine capacity, 
and maintaining adequate supply of essential medical supplies and equipment. Solomon Islands 
and Vanuatu must also contend with the aftermath of Cyclone Harold that struck in April 2020, 
and the duality of the crises requires balancing pandemic prevention and cyclone response 
needs. Other DMCs have also experienced the dual impact of COVID-19 and extreme weather 
events, such as droughts in FSM, RMI, and Palau. 
 
7.  Risk financing. All 10 DMCs have some financial arrangements in place for emergency 
response,  including  annual  contingency  budgets  and,  in  some  cases,  sovereign  disaster 
insurance. Improved access to and management of disaster finance is critical for achieving 
strategic  outcomes  related  to  long-term  resilience.  In  the  event  of  a  significant  disaster, 
governments typically have insufficient resources through budget contingency lines, reserves, or 
insurance to meet immediate financing needs. Instead, they rely heavily on budget reallocations, 
which can take time to secure and often redirect funds away from development priorities. 
Reallocations for emergency response within the health sector budget are particularly concerning 
where these deplete resources for critical health priorities. Supporting better use of emergency 
finance requires strengthening public financial management and expenditure, and ensuring funds 
for emergency response are earmarked, and that budgeting covers gender and social inclusion. 
 
 
 
5  As of 29 October 2020, imported COVID-19 cases or repatriated nationals have been reported in Solomon Islands 
(8) and RMI (2). All cases remain in isolation. The other eight countries remain COVID-19 free.

3 
8.  Development  partner  support.  In  the  aftermath  of  disasters  in  the  Pacific,  major 
development partners—including the governments of Australia, the People’s Republic of China, 
Japan, New Zealand, and the United States—usually move quickly to mobilize immediate relief, 
including in-kind support and financing through humanitarian nongovernment organizations. 
The United Nations’ Pacific Humanitarian Team mobilizes relief and technical support from 
several regional offices. Development partners, including ADB, also provide financing to support 
reconstruction. There is regular coordination between the governments and major development 
partners, including ADB, the World Bank, Australia, and New Zealand, on macroeconomic and 
structural  reforms  and  joint  policy  matrices.  The  policy  dialogue  on  the  CDF  programs  is 
coordinated with World Bank programs with Catastrophe Deferred Drawdown Options.6 
   
9.  ADB engagement and lessons. ADB attaches significant importance to DRM in the 
Pacific, and has provided loans, grants, and technical assistance (TA) for post-disaster response, 
early recovery, and reconstruction. This support has progressively broadened from post-disaster 
assistance to proactive disaster risk reduction (DRR) through various financing mechanisms. ADB 
provides dedicated funding to its concessional assistance-only countries through the Asian 
Development Fund (ADF) 12 DRR financing mechanism; and concessional assistance countries 
can access the ADF 13 (2021–2024) Regional Thematic Pool for DRR purposes. ADB often plays 
a  key  role  in  post-disaster  needs  assessments  that  seek  to  inform  resilient  recovery  and 
reconstruction. For post-disaster humanitarian response, ADB’s Asia Pacific Disaster Response 
Fund can provide grants up to $3 million per event within 1 week of a disaster.7 Additional 
concessional funds can be accessed through the ADF Disaster Response Facility for early 
recovery and reconstruction. Since 2004, ADB has offered an emergency assistance loans 
instrument with extended grace and repayment periods, increased retroactive financing, lower 
interest rates, and streamlined processing requirements, thereby facilitating the approval of fast-
tracked assistance for early recovery purposes.8 Nevertheless, emergency assistance loans can 
still take 3 months or more to process, and reconstruction loans under normal lending modalities 
can  take  significantly  longer.  Therefore,  since 2016,  ADB  has  set  up  contingent  financing 
programs in eight Pacific DMCs to provide more timely post-disaster financing through stand-
alone policy-based loans and grants. In August 2019, ADB formally adopted CDF as an option 
under its policy-based lending policy,9 and in April 2020, ADB approved a special policy variation 
for an initial duration of 15 months that expands the scope of new CDF to include health-related 
emergencies as part of ADB’s response to COVID-19.10 
 
10.  ADB has supported efforts to strengthen the Pacific region’s resilience to infectious 
diseases through the regional vaccines project in Samoa, Tonga, Tuvalu, and Vanuatu.11 In 
addition to the countries drawing down on existing CDF programs, ADB’s immediate and medium-
term response to COVID-19 in the participating countries includes the COVID-19 Pandemic 
Response Option assistance approved for the Cook Islands ($20 million), FSM ($14 million), 
Palau ($20 million), Samoa ($20 million), and Solomon Islands ($20 million).12 A policy-based 
grant that included policy actions on COVID-19 response was also approved for Tonga ($12.2 
million).13 These programs help address the economic and direct health impacts of COVID-19 by

11.  The proposed approach. The program provides Pacific DMCs with a source of financing 
that  can  be  rapidly  disbursed  following  disaster  events.  It  will  complement  risk  financing 
instruments currently in use by the participating governments, including annual contingency 
budgets,  national  disaster  funds,  parametric  disaster  insurance,  and  traditional  indemnity 
insurance. Eligibility to withdraw loan and grant proceeds is based on achieving prior resilience-
related policy actions, but disbursements will be triggered when a state of disaster or emergency 
is declared. The DRM policy actions for each participating DMC will reduce the underlying disaster 
risk and enhance preparedness. Each government has also agreed on an ongoing post-program 
partnership framework (PPPF) to strengthen DRM performance that is based on a gap and needs 
analysis in each country. In addition to disasters caused by natural hazards, the scope of phase 
3 is expanded to cover health-related emergencies in the policy matrices. The DMCs face similar 
challenges and will benefit greatly from a regional approach in which good practices are shared. 
The program will support coordination and cooperation both between Pacific DMCs and with 
development partners on risk financing arrangements and policy reform discussions. The first 
phase of the regional program includes an attached TA, and this has been expanded to include 
the new countries under phase 3.17 The TA project has started country-level support to strengthen 
the policy environment and institutional arrangements for DRM by strengthening post-disaster 
financial management capacity, started work on disaster risk information in some countries, and 
initiated multi-hazard disaster risk assessments. Gender considerations are mainstreamed in the 
country-level support under the TA. 
 
12.  The program is in line with ADB’s Strategy 2030, in particular its operational priority 3 on 
tackling climate change, building climate and disaster resilience, and enhancing environmental 
sustainability, which supports strengthening DMCs’ financial preparedness for disaster response 
through policy-based contingent financing.18 The program aligns with ADB’s operational plan for 
health by strengthening institutions for improved health governance, and enabling health financing 
to tackle public health threats and pandemic preparedness;19 and with the Pacific Approach, 
which serves as ADB’s country partnership strategy for the 11 smaller Pacific DMCs, including 
the 10 countries in this program.20 The Pacific Approach focuses on managing risks as a key 
strategic  area,  and  highlights  the  need  to  (i)  expand  work  on  climate  change  and  DRM;  
(ii) introduce innovative solutions to strengthen disaster preparedness, address vulnerability, and 
build resilience; (iii) pursue a more programmatic and regional approach to financing climate

B.  Policy Reform and ADB’s Value Addition 
 
13.   This phase 3 program will provide another round of financing for countries that drew down 
their CDF programs in 2020 (para. 2), restoring their financial resilience to pre–COVID-19 levels 
ahead of the next cyclone season. In addition to supporting critical DRM actions, the program 
supports urgent measures required by DMCs to prepare for and address the economic impact of 
COVID-19. All 10 countries have made significant progress in strengthening the resilience of 
institutions and communities through three reform areas under phase 3, with policy actions 
completed by October 2020 as outlined below and in the country-specific policy matrices.22 
 
14.   Reform  area  1:  Policy  and  institutional  arrangements  for  risk  management 
strengthened. Resilience considerations were mainstreamed into the new national strategic plan 
in RMI. Long-term preparedness and response plans to COVID-19 and other health emergencies, 
and COVID-19 specific regulations, were developed by all national governments. The Cook 
Islands  and  Samoa  also  prepared  health  emergency  bills,  and  Vanuatu  prepared  a  role 
delineation policy to standardize health systems. In Kiribati, Samoa, Tonga, Tuvalu, and Vanuatu, 
the governments prepared climate change and DRM-related bills. Kiribati also prepared a national 
action  plan  on  climate  change,  incorporating  DRM,  and  considering  gender-differentiated 
vulnerabilities  and  impacts.  A  national  land  subdivision  policy,  incorporating  resilience 
considerations into land and settlement development, was approved for Vanuatu; a national urban 
policy with resilience considerations was approved for Solomon Islands; and a national housing 
recovery and resilience policy was approved for Tonga. The Solomon Islands Maritime Authority 
Board was established, marking a significant step in strengthening the maritime authority’s role in 
emergencies and disaster events; and RMI established new disaster management operational 
arrangements.  The  PPPFs  include  further  actions  in  these  areas  such  as  emergency 
management acts; integrated policies and plans on climate change, DRM, and spatial planning; 
risk-informed land-use and urban policies, as well as hazard and disaster data-sharing policies; 
and public health legislation and policies.  
 
15.   Reform area 2: Risk-informed investment planning processes and tools improved. 
Asset management was strengthened in the Cook Islands, Palau, Samoa and Tuvalu through 
asset management plans and strategies, and improved asset registries and property registration 
and  building  licensing.  In  Palau,  risk  information  has  been  incorporated  into  the  urban 
development strategy and plan, and in Tuvalu, the Funafuti drought monitoring plan was approved 
to improve drought preparedness. Tonga’s new water resources bill incorporated climate and 
disaster resilience considerations. National and/or local-level DRM plans were prepared in the 
Cook Islands, FSM, Samoa, Tonga, and Tuvalu; and integrated vulnerability assessments were 
approved in Tuvalu using a whole-of-island approach to inform the decision-making process. 
In RMI  and  Tonga,  sector  or  cluster  specific  standard  operating  procedures  and  terms  of 
reference were developed. Kiribati finalized a strategic roadmap for emergency management. 
Cross-sectoral table-top exercises were carried out in FSM and RMI to strengthen emergency 
preparedness. Health sector-specific emergency plans and regulations were prepared in all

C.  Impacts of the Reform 
 
18.   The impact of the program is aligned with goals 1 (strengthened integrated adaptation and 
risk reduction to enhance resilience to climate change and disasters) and 3 (strengthened disaster 
preparedness, response and recovery) of the Framework for Resilient Development in the Pacific 
(footnote 21). The program is also aligned to objective 1 of the regional COVID-19 health sector 
support plan to expand country readiness and response operations.23 The program will provide a 
timely and predictable source of emergency financing to facilitate rapid implementation of priority 
actions, and reduce the indirect economic and social costs of direct physical losses.  
 
19.   The policy actions will encourage reforms that ultimately result in economic benefits by 
addressing the constraints that have been identified in DRM. The economic impact of the policy 
actions will depend on the scale and type of disaster event, and geographic area of impact. Under 
reform area 1, potential benefits will include reduced loss of lives and property, and reduced costs 
due to shorter business and public facility closures. These benefits will result from improved 
planning and response and faster restoration of essential infrastructure and services. Under 
reform area 2, benefits will include reduced damage to property, improved public safety, and 
reduced health impacts. These will result from improved sector planning, improved response and 
preparedness to disasters and health-related emergencies, and more resilient infrastructure and 
assets. Under reform area 3, the opportunity costs associated with budget reallocations and 
financial costs associated with additional borrowing will be reduced, while the economic stimulus 
packages will reduce the income loss of vulnerable households and businesses.

D.  Development Financing Needs and Budget Support 
 
20.   During the initial availability period of 2021–2023, the overall development financing needs 
of participating governments are estimated to be 10.2%–25.4% of gross domestic product (GDP) 
per annum, with 12.5% to 16.2% of GDP to be mobilized from external financing, predominantly 
as grants.24 The post-disaster financing needs have been determined based on the likely fiscal 
impact of medium- to low-frequency disasters, taking into account resources available from 
domestic and international sources, the need to maintain sustainable levels of debt, and the 
availability of concessional resources. Although data on historical losses are incomplete, analysis 
undertaken under the Pacific Catastrophe Risk Assessment and Financing Initiative indicates that 
average annual losses from cyclones, earthquakes, and tsunamis alone are equivalent to 2.0% 
of GDP in the Cook Islands, 2.9% in FSM, 0.2% in Kiribati, 2.0% in RMI, 1.6% in Palau, 1.7% in 
Samoa, 3.0% in Solomon Islands, 4.3% in Tonga, 0.8% in Tuvalu, and 6.6% in Vanuatu. Probable 
maximum losses for a 1-in-50-year event (limited to cyclones, earthquakes, and tsunamis) are 
estimated at $56.8 million for the Cook Islands, $75.3 million for FSM, $0.4 million for Kiribati, 
$34.1 million for RMI, $16.8 million for Palau, $109.8 million for Samoa, $189.6 million for 
Solomon  Islands,  $140.2  million  for  Tonga,  $2.8 million  for  Tuvalu,  and  $61.4  million  for 
Vanuatu.25 In addition to cyclones, earthquakes and tsunamis, frequent flooding and drought 
events are causing recurrent losses in the participating countries, with a cumulative impact on 
livelihoods and economies. The 10 countries also experience storm surges, health emergencies 
and, in some cases, volcanic eruptions.  
 
21.  Recent examples of disasters in the participating countries include Cyclone Harold in April 
2020, which caused damage and loss estimated at $453 million (46% of GDP) in Vanuatu; and 
$111 million (25% of GDP) in Tonga. Other examples include Cyclone Gita in 2018, which caused 
damage equivalent to 38% of GDP in Tonga; Cyclone Pam in 2015 with estimated damage and

III.  DUE DILIGENCE 
 
25.   In compliance with ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement (2009), the program is classified 
as category C for environment, involuntary resettlement, and indigenous peoples safeguards.33 
Program activities are confined to policy and institutional reforms, and none of the activities will 
result in or lead to any physical works that could create environmental or social impacts, physical 
or economic displacement, or involuntary resettlement. The activities will not negatively affect 
indigenous peoples. Stakeholder dialogue was carried out during the program design and will 
continue during implementation. The policy actions will improve the participating countries’ ability 
to maintain greater fiscal stability in the event of a disaster or health emergency and to initiate 
relief and recovery efforts with minimum delay, thereby reducing the immediate economic and 
social impacts of the event. Implementation of the policy actions is expected to continue to 
strengthen existing social protection arrangements, helping to ensure that communities and 
vulnerable households (including households headed by women) can receive support to rebuild 
their lives and assets. The policy actions on COVID-19 response will benefit vulnerable groups 
such as older people and those with pre-existing co-morbidities, as they will be disproportionately 
affected by the potential direct impacts of the COVID-19 pandemic. 
 
26.   The program is classified effective gender mainstreaming. Women are impacted by 
disasters and health emergencies in different and often overlooked ways. The program will 
directly benefit women by ensuring gender is a core component of key strategic and policy 
documents.  Gender-responsive  policy  and  institutional  arrangements  for  risk  management

disaster situations (RMI, Tuvalu, and Vanuatu). Investment planning processes and tools that 
support women and girls include community integrated management plans for climate and 
disaster resilience that promote the participation of women in DRM decision-making (Samoa and 
Tonga); Cyclone Tino Recovery and Vulnerability Reduction Plan allocating funding for gender

metadata.Subject: The proposed CDF program will improve the resilience of the participating Asian Development Bank (ADB) Pacific developing member countries (DMCs) to disasters triggered by natural hazards and health emergencies. It will support policy actions strengthening resilience to disasters and provide a source of financing for timely emergency response and early recovery.The report and recommendation of the President to the Board of Directors (RRP) document describes the terms and conditions of a project for consideration and approval by ADB's Board of Directors.This document dated November 2020 is provided for the ADB regional project 50028-003.
